title: Does eternity have a beginning? - Quora

response.answer_text: Eternity implies that it will last forever. Mathmatically, forever, or infinity, means it will go on forever. BUT, think of the equation sqrt(x). It starts at zero and continues forever in ONE direction. By this logic, it DOES have a beginning. Thinking about the creation of the univers, it is infinitly expanding in all directions. But what set all this in motion? There had to be a point where everything was at one point, like sqrt(x) but in three dimensions and in all degrees. So that would be the beginning of that infinity. Eternity practically means forever, so yes I believe there was a beginning to eternity, the moment the concept of infinity was created naturally.

Because man lives in a created order of which time is a part (Hebrews 1:2), we will not understand what it means when one says that eternity means ‘no beginning, no ending.’ Only God understans eternity fully since He alone is eternal (1 Timothy 1:17). Even the words used in the Bible to speak of eternity come from a world governed by time.. In the real sense, eternity is beyond the scope of human comprehension. Since God is not limited by time, thus sees time differently from the way man sees it (2 Peter 3:8), we should regard eternity simply as ‘immeasurable time’ or using biblical expressions: from age to age which have been translated as from everlasting to everlasting and for ever and ever (Nehemiah 9:5; Psalm 21:4; Romans 1:25; Ephesians 3:21; Jude 25).

No, if “eternity” is the translation of sanskrit “sat”. The answer is “acintya”—inconceivable by the mind which is trapped in past-present-future—but knowable through yoga as a process of purifying consiousness (sanskrit “chit”). The process is achievable by anyone willing to apply the discipline codified in the aphorisms of Patanjali and under the guidance of a qualified teacher. This is not a question of belief—beliefs and belief systems are of the mind and must also be rejected and replaced with consciousness purified through yoga—direct perception of truth. Om-Tat-Sat.
G-d is the beginning so beginning and the End itself is G-d. Eternity began from G-d. G-d is everlasting.
